item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:17, topic:437939”][quote author=Aftermath link=topic=540654.msg3960091#msg3960091 date=1333203574]

Sorry, I should have added the qualification - it’s vulnerable if the user is ever allowed to select a particular game to view the information for (for example, by viewing the game’s page).

If you’re just looping over all games in the database and that’s the only thing calling your functions then it’s fine.

Well the href link is going to take the user to a separate php page where the flash game object (url probably loaded from the db as well) will be placed, with a small description, and the controls below, does that count? Was also thinking of placing the game description paragraph in the same db table with a longtext type, would that be sensible?

This seems fine to me as long as you don’t make any query parameters (for example game ID) specifiable from the client side. Also, I wouldn’t be able to tell you what string types are appropriate to use.
[/quote]
Uhm, so having the url as /games/$GAME_ID.php wouldn’t be very secure? :P[/quote]
That should be fine as long as the pages actually exist on the file system and aren’t dynamically served. (What I mean is, that /games/string.php should serve an error because that page doesn’t exist instead of looking up the game ‘string’ in the database and serving a page based on that). It’s very unlikely that you’re serving pages dynamically, so I don’t see a problem with that.

The takeaway is just to not use values from GET or POST in your queries without checking them first. For example, game.php?id=1 (GET) or id=1 via form (POST).

item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:13, topic:437939”][quote author=Aftermath link=topic=540654.msg3960082#msg3960082 date=1333202413]

Sure you can. Just print the html from PHP instead of breaking out of PHP mode.

$numGames = 8; for($i = 0; $i < numGames; $i++) { print '<div class="game-container">'; .... $gameDate = GetGameDate($i, 'plays', 'DESC'); print "<h2>Added on $gameDate</h2>"; .... }

That’s brilliant, thank you, I can see that working. Do you reckon that can easily be adapted to suit the genre based links, which are going to display games only of that genre?
Also I heard echo is faster than print, is that true?

Yep. Assuming the genres are strings (or whatever else), have an array of them and just loop over the indices in the same way.

Also, I have no idea if echo is faster than print. If there’s a difference it will be so small I’m almost certain it doesn’t matter at your scale.

http://www.phpbench.com/ says [quote]In reality the echo and print functions serve the exact purpose and therefore in the backend the exact same code applies. The one small thing to notice is that when using a comma to separate items whilst using the echo function, items run slightly faster.[/quote]

http://www.learnphponline.com/php-basics/php-echo-vs-print

Oh great, many thanks, will implement this when I finish work later.

I know I’m asking a lot, but can you see any major security flaws at the moment? I’m really a beginner with server side programming, and I haven’t read into how mysql injection works yet.

Yep, it’s vulnerable. Anyone can run any arbitrary SQL command.
[/quote]
Oh, shite well I’ll worry about that if the site ever becomes anything more than just a learning project, cheers :P[/quote]
Sorry, I should have added the qualification - it’s vulnerable if the user is ever allowed to select a particular game to view the information for (for example, by viewing the game’s page).

If you’re just looping over all games in the database and that’s the only thing calling your functions then it’s fine.

(e.g. it’s vulnerable if the user can visit gameInfo.php?id=1 and you use the value of id without checking it’s actually a number before passing it to the function).
